author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.en: Linked Discourses 22
1. Nakula’s Father
2. At Devadaha
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati devadahaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Devadaha.

segments.pli: Atha kho sambahulā pacchābhūmagamikā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then several mendicants who were heading for the west went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

segments.pli: “icchāma mayaṃ, bhante, pacchābhūmaṃ janapadaṃ gantuṃ, pacchābhūme janapade nivāsaṃ kappetun”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, we wish to go to a western land to take up residence there.”
“But mendicants, have you consulted with Sāriputta?”

segments.pli: “Na kho no, bhante, apalokito āyasmā sāriputto”ti.
segments.en: “No, sir, we haven’t.”
“You should consult with Sāriputta.

segments.pli: Sāriputto, bhikkhave, paṇḍito, bhikkhūnaṃ anuggāhako sabrahmacārīnan”ti.
segments.en: He’s astute, and supports his spiritual companions, the mendicants.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato avidūre aññatarasmiṃ eḷagalāgumbe nisinno hoti.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was meditating not far from the Buddha in a clump of golden shower trees.

segments.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
segments.en: And then those mendicants approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him,

segments.pli: “icchāma mayaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, pacchābhūmaṃ janapadaṃ gantuṃ, pacchābhūme janapade nivāsaṃ kappetuṃ.
segments.en: “Reverend Sāriputta, we wish to go to a western land to take up residence there.
We have consulted with the Teacher.”
“Reverends, there are those who question a mendicant who has gone abroad—
astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
for astute people are inquisitive:

segments.pli: ‘kiṃvādī panāyasmantānaṃ satthā kimakkhāyī’ti, kacci vo āyasmantānaṃ dhammā sussutā suggahitā sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā suppaṭividdhā paññāya, yathā byākaramānā āyasmanto vuttavādino ceva bhagavato assatha, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyātha, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākareyyātha, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgaccheyyā”ti?
segments.en: ‘But what does the venerables’ Teacher teach? What does he explain?’ I trust the venerables have properly heard, learned, attended, and remembered the teachings, and penetrated them with wisdom. That way, when answering you will repeat what the Buddha has said and not misrepresent him with an untruth. You will explain in line with the teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism.

segments.pli: “Dūratopi kho mayaṃ, āvuso, āgaccheyyāma āyasmato sāriputtassa santike etassa bhāsitassa atthamaññātuṃ.
segments.en: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.

segments.pli: Sādhu vatāyasmantaṃyeva sāriputtaṃ paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho”ti.
segments.en: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.”

segments.pli: “Tena hāvuso, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” they replied.
Sāriputta said this:
“Reverends, there are those who question a mendicant who has gone abroad—
astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics—
for astute people are inquisitive:
‘But what does the venerables’ Teacher teach? What does he explain?’

segments.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
segments.en: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:
‘Reverend, our Teacher explained the removal of desire and lust.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ byākatepi kho, āvuso, assuyeva uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchitāro—
segments.en: When you answer like this, such astute people may inquire further:
‘But regarding what does the venerables’ teacher explain the removal of desire and lust?’

segments.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
segments.en: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:
‘Our teacher explains the removal of desire and lust for form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ byākatepi kho, āvuso, assuyeva uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchitāro—
segments.en: When you answer like this, such astute people may inquire further:

segments.pli: ‘kiṃ panāyasmantānaṃ ādīnavaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā,
segments.en: ‘But what drawback has he seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness?’

segments.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
segments.en: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:

segments.pli: ‘rūpe kho, āvuso, avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
segments.en: ‘If you’re not free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes it gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
If you’re not free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for feeling …
perception …
choices …

segments.pli: avigatataṇhassa tesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
Viññāṇe avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
segments.en: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes it gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

segments.pli: Idaṃ kho no, āvuso, ādīnavaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā,
segments.en: This is the drawback our Teacher has seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ byākatepi kho, āvuso, assuyeva uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchitāro—
segments.en: When you answer like this, such astute people may inquire further:

segments.pli: ‘kiṃ panāyasmantānaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā,
segments.en: ‘But what benefit has he seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form,
feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness?’

segments.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, āvuso, evaṃ byākareyyātha:
segments.en: When questioned like this, reverends, you should answer:

segments.pli: ‘rūpe kho, āvuso, vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā nuppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
segments.en: ‘If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for feeling …
perception …

segments.pli: saṅkhāresu vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā nuppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
segments.en: choices …

segments.pli: Viññāṇe vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā nuppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā.
segments.en: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

segments.pli: Idaṃ kho no, āvuso, ānisaṃsaṃ disvā rūpe chandarāgavinayakkhāyī satthā, vedanāya …
segments.en: This is the benefit our Teacher has seen that he teaches the removal of desire and lust for form, feeling,
perception,
choices,
and consciousness.’

segments.pli: Akusale cāvuso, dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme sukho vihāro abhavissa avighāto anupāyāso apariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugati pāṭikaṅkhā, nayidaṃ bhagavā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ vaṇṇeyya.
segments.en: If those who acquired and kept unskillful qualities were to live happily in the present life, free of anguish, distress, and fever; and if, when their body breaks up, after death, they could expect to go to a good place, the Buddha would not praise giving up unskillful qualities.

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, akusale dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkho vihāro savighāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā, tasmā bhagavā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānaṃ vaṇṇeti.
segments.en: But since those who acquire and keep unskillful qualities live unhappily in the present life, full of anguish, distress, and fever; and since, when their body breaks up, after death, they can expect to go to a bad place, the Buddha praises giving up unskillful qualities.

segments.pli: Kusale cāvuso, dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme dukkho vihāro abhavissa savighāto saupāyāso sapariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā duggati pāṭikaṅkhā, nayidaṃ bhagavā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ vaṇṇeyya.
segments.en: If those who embraced and kept skillful qualities were to live unhappily in the present life, full of anguish, distress, and fever; and if, when their body breaks up, after death, they could expect to go to a bad place, the Buddha would not praise embracing skillful qualities.

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso, kusale dhamme upasampajja viharato diṭṭhe ceva dhamme sukho vihāro avighāto anupāyāso apariḷāho, kāyassa ca bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugati pāṭikaṅkhā, tasmā bhagavā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadaṃ vaṇṇetī”ti.
segments.en: But since those who embrace and keep skillful qualities live happily in the present life, free of anguish, distress, and fever; and since, when their body breaks up, after death, they can expect to go to a good place, the Buddha praises embracing skillful qualities.”
This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.

segments.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
segments.en: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Sāriputta said.

suttaplex.blurb: A number of mendicants are heading for lands west, but the Buddha advises them to speak with Sāriputta before they go. Sāriputta reminds them that in foreign lands they will be scrutinized for their understanding, so they need to be able to answer questions on the teaching. He goes on to explain that the Dhamma is for the removal of desire  for the five aggregates.
